comments.body: @yxieca could you please help to review or assing someone to do so?

@wangxin Hi Xin, do you think it makes sense to disable Loganalyzer for tests that includes a `config reload` or `config load_minigraph`? The logs during service being terminated and restarted are difficult to forcast. Many unexpected ERRORs or WARNINGs can be seen.

Hi @wangxin @ZhaohuiS 
Noticed test_telemetry_output is still failing at this cmd on 202012 test branch:

2022-09-17T07:17:09.6730990Z     "cmd": "python /gnxi/gnmi_cli_py/py_gnmicli.py -g -t 10.3.147.150 -p 50051 -m get -x COUNTERS/Ethernet0 -xt COUNTERS_DB            -o "ndastreamingservertest"", 

2022-09-17T07:17:09.6787480Z     "stderr": "Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/gnxi/gnmi_cli_py/py_gnmicli.py", line 510, in <module>
    main()
  File "/gnxi/gnmi_cli_py/py_gnmicli.py", line 477, in main
    response = _get(stub, paths, user, password, prefix)
  File "/gnxi/gnmi_cli_py/py_gnmicli.py", line 297, in _get
    **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 550, in __call__
    return _end_unary_response_blocking(state, call, False, None)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 467, in _end_unary_response_blocking
    raise _Rendezvous(state, None, None, deadline)
grpc._channel._Rendezvous: <_Rendezvous of RPC that terminated with:
	status = StatusCode.NOT_FOUND
	details = "redis: nil"
	debug_error_string = "{"created":"@1663399029.573632194","description":"Error received from peer","file":"src/core/lib/surface/call.cc","file_line":1036,"grpc_message":"redis: nil","grpc_status":5}"
>", 

any idea why it failed? thanks

> 202012

@wenyiz2021
I searched test results, telemetry.test_telemetry.test_telemetry_ouput failed on 3164 with 201911 image.
After reading test cases, I think this case should be skipped  for 201911 or older image. 

```
    skip_201911_and_older(duthost)
    cmd = generate_client_cli(duthost=duthost, gnxi_path=gnxi_path, method=METHOD_GET, target="OTHERS", xpath="osversion/build")

```

```
def skip_201911_and_older(duthost):
    """ Skip the current test if the DUT version is 201911 or older.
    """
    if parse_version(duthost.kernel_version) <= parse_version('4.9.0'):
        pytest.skip("Test not supported for 201911 images. Skipping the test")
```

It's better to check os version instead of kernel version and move it to tests_mark_conditions.yml.

> > 202012
> 
> @wenyiz2021 I searched test results, telemetry.test_telemetry.test_telemetry_ouput failed on 3164 with 201911 image. After reading test cases, I think this case should be skipped for 201911 or older image.
> 
> ```
>     skip_201911_and_older(duthost)
>     cmd = generate_client_cli(duthost=duthost, gnxi_path=gnxi_path, method=METHOD_GET, target="OTHERS", xpath="osversion/build")
> ```
> 
> ```
> def skip_201911_and_older(duthost):
>     """ Skip the current test if the DUT version is 201911 or older.
>     """
>     if parse_version(duthost.kernel_version) <= parse_version('4.9.0'):
>         pytest.skip("Test not supported for 201911 images. Skipping the test")
> ```
> 
> It's better to check os version instead of kernel version and move it to tests_mark_conditions.yml.

thanks @ZhaohuiS I'll raise a PR to skip test_telemetry_output in test_conditional_mark.yml

@AntonHryshchuk In your RP #5291, I don't quite understand your implementation. Could you please try to answer my questions?

1. If fanouthost is onyx, it will skip the test case, because  pytest.SKIP_COUNTERS_FOR_MLNX = True
Then why you still call prepare_drop_counter_config?
```
    if fanouthost.os == 'onyx':
        pytest.SKIP_COUNTERS_FOR_MLNX = True
        src_mac = "00:00:00:00:00:11"
        # Prepare openflow rule
        fanouthost.prepare_drop_counter_config(
            fanout_graph_facts=fanout_graph_facts, match_mac=src_mac, set_mac=ports_info["dst_mac"], eth_field="eth_src")
```
2. fanouthost in your implementation is a list, it looks like this:
`fanouthost = { os: 'eos', hostname: 'str-7260-24', device_type: 'FanoutLeaf' }`
So ` fanouthost.prepare_drop_counter_config` doesn't make sense. I think you should import `onyx `module to call it.
@AntonHryshchuk Could you please review this PR? I am not sure if the changes will block the test on your side. Thanks.

Hi @ZhaohuiS,


> If fanouthost is onyx, it will skip the test case, because pytest.SKIP_COUNTERS_FOR_MLNX = True
Then why you still call prepare_drop_counter_config?

The reason there is  pytest.SKIP_COUNTERS_FOR_MLNX global variable is the same reason the test cases are in a separate file (drop_packets.py instead of test_drop_counters.py). please check https://github.com/noaOrMlnx/SONiC/blob/9d5438a55f1a877b2fbd1da612566ff732ed5ee2/docs/what-just-happened/what-just-happened_test_plan.md
The infrastructure was changed in order to have the ability for different vendors to create their own internal tests and rely on the existing drop_packets infra. 
So if pytest.SKIP_COUNTERS_FOR_MLNX = True, mellanox will still need the fanout config changes for other internal tests running. 


>fanouthost in your implementation is a list, it looks like this:
fanouthost = { os: 'eos', hostname: 'str-7260-24', device_type: 'FanoutLeaf' }
So fanouthost.prepare_drop_counter_config doesn't make sense. I think you should import onyx module to call it.

You are right. Need to check and change it.


>Could you please review this PR? I am not sure if the changes will block the test on your side. Thanks.

The code LGTM.
I tested your changes on our system - no failures.

> Hi @ZhaohuiS,
> 
> > If fanouthost is onyx, it will skip the test case, because pytest.SKIP_COUNTERS_FOR_MLNX = True
> > Then why you still call prepare_drop_counter_config?
> 
> The reason there is pytest.SKIP_COUNTERS_FOR_MLNX global variable is the same reason the test cases are in a separate file (drop_packets.py instead of test_drop_counters.py). please check https://github.com/noaOrMlnx/SONiC/blob/9d5438a55f1a877b2fbd1da612566ff732ed5ee2/docs/what-just-happened/what-just-happened_test_plan.md The infrastructure was changed in order to have the ability for different vendors to create their own internal tests and rely on the existing drop_packets infra. So if pytest.SKIP_COUNTERS_FOR_MLNX = True, mellanox will still need the fanout config changes for other internal tests running.
> 
> > fanouthost in your implementation is a list, it looks like this:
> > fanouthost = { os: 'eos', hostname: 'str-7260-24', device_type: 'FanoutLeaf' }
> > So fanouthost.prepare_drop_counter_config doesn't make sense. I think you should import onyx module to call it.
> 
> You are right. Need to check and change it.
> 
> > Could you please review this PR? I am not sure if the changes will block the test on your side. Thanks.
> 
> The code LGTM. I tested your changes on our system - no failures.

Thank you for your reply, Anton.

Merged PR: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/5319 to see if help multi-asic qos tests to pass.
Reason for this suspection: 
Manual run of all test_qos_sai.py will fail on multi-asic qos tests, but independently run multi-asic qos test ONLY will pass. This refactor of separating MASIC into separate class might help on this, as old design have dependency on other qos tests for multi-asic qos tests, where in other qos tests BGP control packets are filtered so that they are not sent out, which causes BGP sessions to go down.

> Please verify that the testcases work fine on a single asic device as well

This pull request **introduces 2 alerts** when merging 47062e9d8f4dfcedef0154a42cfc44e89b2785c0 into bd17176d4affe0853b0513722fe74bd9eb4efe7d - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-7cd2c96417f9b69e6ae4fc7beecc010951c257ef)

**new alerts:**

* 2 for Variable defined multiple times

Now that there are different QoS mappings between downlink and uplink in leaf router and dual ToR, is there a way to cover the different mapping behaviors? This can be done by choosing different source ports and DSCPs.

Currently, the logic in many QoS tests are:
1. Choose a source port randomly or according to the `qos.yml`
2. Generate traffic and check corresponding counters (like drop, PFC) for DSCP 3 and 4.

To cover different mappings you may want to do it in this way:
1. Choose a source port from each of the following set
    - ports connected between dual-ToR and the leaf router
    - other ports
2. Generate traffic and check counters for corresponding DSCP
    - 2, 3, 4, 6 for ports between dual-ToR and leaf routers
    - 3, 4 for other ports

> Now that there are different QoS mappings between downlink and uplink in leaf router and dual ToR, is there a way to cover the different mapping behaviors? This can be done by choosing different source ports and DSCPs.
> 
> Currently, the logic in many QoS tests are:
> 
> 1. Choose a source port randomly or according to the `qos.yml`
> 2. Generate traffic and check corresponding counters (like drop, PFC) for DSCP 3 and 4.
> 
> To cover different mappings you may want to do it in this way:
> 
> 1. Choose a source port from each of the following set
>    
>    * ports connected between dual-ToR and the leaf router
>    * other ports
> 2. Generate traffic and check counters for corresponding DSCP
>    
>    * 2, 3, 4, 6 for ports between dual-ToR and leaf routers
>    * 3, 4 for other ports

Different mapping feature is still work in progress. We can request this along with the feature PR.

comments.body: @ppikh this test has lots of "with allure..." blocks, if allure is not configured, what is the impact to this test?

Hi,

It requires only allure lib installed(which is already part of sonic-mgmt docker.
If allure not installed(if run not from sonic-mgmt) - it will fail, but it’s not our case.
If user provide allure dir as test argument - then user will be able to see allure report, id not - the test will be executed without allure report.

I added logic which will skip test case in case when allure lib missed.

```
try:
    import allure
except ImportError:
    pytest.skip('Allure library not available. Skipping tests')
```

I will check if it pass on KVM switch later. If it will pass on KWM switch - I will create separate commit in which I will add test to kvmtests.sh.
For now please merge it without KVM.
Thanks

> 
@kevinskwang [this PR](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/2198) by @dgsudharsan should fix this
Those cases looks good to me~ Just one question, why expect the overlay DMAC still to be the dut_mac after encap? should it be the dest VM's MAC in the vnet?

> 




> Those cases looks good to me~ Just one question, why expect the overlay DMAC still to be the dut_mac after encap? should it be the dest VM's MAC in the vnet?
Hi @kevinskwang : I agree with you, it is actually ignored in the test. So it is ok.

This pull request **fixes 1 alert** when merging 85e3ffe86de57fd29b6a05f48c4acf73c7018da2 into da9fed94ddd1900881eb0b222a2aaccc3c2e3161 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-18279d6a1425e0438b6aa34d04c48d556bd1a468)

**fixed alerts:**

* 1 for Unused import

> > 
> 
> > Those cases looks good to me~ Just one question, why expect the overlay DMAC still to be the dut_mac after encap? should it be the dest VM's MAC in the vnet?
> > Hi @kevinskwang : I agree with you, it is actually ignored in the test. So it is ok.

But I didn't see set_do_not_care_scapy() is invoked for the overlay DMAC. Additionally, if captured packet on ptf rx side, the overlay DMAC is still using the original IP packet's DMAC.

> > > 
> > 
> > 
> > > Those cases looks good to me~ Just one question, why expect the overlay DMAC still to be the dut_mac after encap? should it be the dest VM's MAC in the vnet?
> > > Hi @kevinskwang : I agree with you, it is actually ignored in the test. So it is ok.
> 
> But I didn't see set_do_not_care_scapy() is invoked for the overlay DMAC. Additionally, if captured packet on ptf rx side, the overlay DMAC is still using the original IP packet's DMAC.

Hi @kevinskwang : I misunderstood. As per my understanding of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc7348/, the payload(or overlay) remains the same as the original.  So the overlay DMAC is still going to be the MAC that we send from the PTF. The underlay(or VxLAN header's ethernet part) should contain AristaVMs' mac as the dest mac.

> > > > 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > > Those cases looks good to me~ Just one question, why expect the overlay DMAC still to be the dut_mac after encap? should it be the dest VM's MAC in the vnet?
> > > > Hi @kevinskwang : I agree with you, it is actually ignored in the test. So it is ok.
> > 
> > 
> > But I didn't see set_do_not_care_scapy() is invoked for the overlay DMAC. Additionally, if captured packet on ptf rx side, the overlay DMAC is still using the original IP packet's DMAC.
> 
> Hi @kevinskwang : I misunderstood. As per my understanding of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc7348/, the payload(or overlay) remains the same as the original. So the overlay DMAC is still going to be the MAC that we send from the PTF. The underlay(or VxLAN header's ethernet part) should contain AristaVMs' mac as the dest mac.

Thats not true. Overlay DMAC must be changed by the pipeline if the following attribute is set:

```
    /**
     * @brief Default VXLAN router MAC (inner destination MAC for VXLAN encapsulation)
     *
     * @type sai_mac_t
     * @flags CREATE_AND_SET
     * @default vendor
     */
    SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_VXLAN_DEFAULT_ROUTER_MAC,
```

Similarly for port:

```
    /**
     * @brief Default VXLAN destination UDP port
     *
     * @type sai_uint16_t
     * @flags CREATE_AND_SET
     * @isvlan false
     * @default 4789
     */
    SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_VXLAN_DEFAULT_PORT,
```

@rraghav-cisco I see that there is no wait between route removal and portchannel, vnet removal https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/85e3ffe86de57fd29b6a05f48c4acf73c7018da2/tests/vxlan/test_vxlan_ecmp.py#L617 This results in vrf removal if the number of routes are huge. Can you please some deterministic check and proceed to remove only portchannel, vnet only when all routes are removed?

Mar 29 18:18:23.508200 r-tigon-11 ERR swss#orchagent: :- meta_generic_validation_remove: object 0x3000000000002 reference count is 13028, can't remove
Mar 29 18:18:23.508200 r-tigon-11 ERR swss#orchagent: :- ~VNetVrfObject: Failed to remove virtual router name: Vnet_v4_in_v6-0, rv:-17

@dgsudharsan : Thanks for trying the script. Did you run it at scale? I will add a delay in the apply_config_in_swss() function, based on my calculations. This will allow a delay for every change(SET or DEL) in the vnet routes. Hope that works.

latestReviews.body: Thanks @rraghav-cisco , @ihorchekh, @roysr-nv for the great contributions on implementation and review

reviews.body:
Hi,

Can you please provide the runtime of this test suite, how much time would it take to run the entire suite?

Can you please use allure steps, rather than comments, it would make the allure report much more readable.
Here are some suggestions from my side.
Thanks @rraghav-cisco , @ihorchekh, @roysr-nv for the great contributions on implementation and review

comments.body: @sanmalho-git - please help to review. Thanks.

Few questions @kartik-arista @ysmanman -
1.A - Are we planning to test fabric ports/links from SUP side only or line card side as well? 
1.B - Do we have support to show link connectivity/reachability from line card?  If not, it will be good to add that and can be helpful during traffic loss/error scenarios.

2.A - Do we have any fabric link monitoring support? 
2.B - Can it take action to shutdown specific links if error reaches certain threshold? 
2.C - Do we know how many links can be shut down without affecting line rate for the chassis? 

3.A - Is it possible to verify/check congestion in the fabric chip ? e.g. Can fabric counter show flow control, FIFO level along with other counters? Will these counters mentioned in the HLD be helpful for this task -
     SAI_QUEUE_STAT_WATERMARK_LEVEL,
    SAI_QUEUE_STAT_CURR_OCCUPANCY_BYTES,
    SAI_QUEUE_STAT_CURR_OCCUPANCY_LEVEL

Few questions @kartik-arista @ysmanman -
1.A - Are we planning to test fabric ports/links from SUP side only or line card side as well?
1.B - Do we have support to show link connectivity/reachability from line card? If not, it will be good to add that and can be helpful during traffic loss/error scenarios.
=> Yes completely agreed. This was not considered within the scope of the initial effort which was focussed on fabric cards, but we can certainly take it on as a follow on. However, there are diag commands that can report this information today for troubleshooting purposes.

2.A - Do we have any fabric link monitoring support?
2.B - Can it take action to shutdown specific links if error reaches certain threshold?
=> The fabric hardware already has built-in mechanisms to monitor errors and automatically take misbehaving links out of service, so this is not mandatory. However, we can certainly consider introducing more active monitoring where we implement more aggressive actions without waiting for the hardware to take action. We will discuss internally and come back with a proposal.

2.C - Do we know how many links can be shut down without affecting line rate for the chassis?
=> This is very much a hardware design specific consideration, but at a high level, the fabric links are highly over-provisioned, so even taking out something 1/4 of links between a card and the fabric (which is a sign of much bigger misbehavior anyway) will not have any bandwidth impact.


3.A - Is it possible to verify/check congestion in the fabric chip ? e.g. Can fabric counter show flow control, FIFO level along with other counters? Will these counters mentioned in the HLD be helpful for this task -
SAI_QUEUE_STAT_WATERMARK_LEVEL,
SAI_QUEUE_STAT_CURR_OCCUPANCY_BYTES,
SAI_QUEUE_STAT_CURR_OCCUPANCY_LEVEL
=> The fabric is significantly over-provisioned, so inducing any kind of congestion scenario requires very high traffic rates. Hence it may not be practical to create these test cases. As above, we can use chip diag commands to display these watermarks and levels in detail.

Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).
One concern is hardcoding values in json file, e.g. Nexthop IP, interface names etc. It will be better if these files can be generated by getting the interface names and nexthops at run time.

I understand the scope is MPLS basic forwarding. In addition to the tests you already listed, I think more can be added for basic MPLS forwarding tests. For e.g following test cases should be added for label forwarding tests. Feel free to add more.

POP - multi label, only top label should be poppped

NHOP ECMP:
- Multiple label next hops
- Multiple label and IP next hops

LABEL ECMP
- Load balancing for label, (src/dst IP remains same, change label)
- Mupltiple labels. Verify ECMP, change the outermost label

LABEL ECMP - port flap
- bring down a port - check load balancing
- bring up the port - check load balancing

MPLS QoS
- Verify QoS mapping between IP and MPLS at ingress
- Verify QoS mapping between IP and MPLS at egress

MAX Labels test
- pick 4 labels as MAX, push labels and verify forwarding

Negative test case:
- Send MPLS traffic on i/f with no MPLS enabled - traffic must be dropped
